title: ASL 7.8 — Pharmacy & Prescriptions
objectives: Use time-sequencing (morning, night, weekly) in context

sections.heading: Context: Pharmacy Visit
sections.body: Use clear directional verbs: DOCTOR GIVE-ME PRESCRIPTION. PHARMACY GIVE-ME PILL.

sections.heading: Dosage & Timing
sections.body: Practice expressions: TAKE PILL MORNING NIGHT. TAKE MEDICINE 3-DAY. Stress **time-first** rule (TIME + ACTION).

microCheck.q: What comes first when signing instructions?

sections.heading: Partner Dialogue
sections.body:
Role-play: A is pharmacist, B is patient.
1. Ask for prescription.
2. Clarify dosage.
3. Close with THANK-YOU.

callouts.title: Sample Exchange
callouts.body: A: YOU HAVE PRESCRIPTION?  B: YES, DOCTOR GIVE-ME.  A: TAKE PILL ONCE-A-DAY.  B: THANK-YOU.

items.q: Correct gloss: Take medicine 3 times a day
Write an ASL gloss for 'Take one pill at night'.

items.prompt: How comfortable are you explaining dosage? Which signs need more practice?

reflectionPrompt: Record yourself signing: 'Doctor give-me prescription. Pharmacy give-me medicine. Take one pill every morning.'
summary: You can now discuss prescriptions and dosage clearly, using time-first rules and pharmacy vocabulary.
